div.head: A Rational Diſcours touching the Ʋniverſal Medicin.
div.p: BEing now confined to on Sheet and a half, I cannot therfor to the convincment and amazment of al gain-ſayers, as indeed wel I could, (wer ther but mor Paper allowed me) inlarg on this Subject; but only in a few words hint at theſ eight Points. 1. The Diviſion of Medicins. 2. The Nullity of a Specifical Purgativ. 3. The Neceſſity of an Univerſal Medicin. 4. That Specifick Purgativs uſed as Catholicks ar not ſo dangerous as Reſtorativs, adminiſtred alſo upon the ſam account. 5. The proper and genuin uſ of Specificks. 6. The Conſiſtenc of Medicins. 7. The uſ of this min Univerſal Purgativ: Together with the Doſ and Pric therof, wher it is to be had, and from whom. 8. An Account of the Author himſelf.

div.head: SECT. 1. The Diviſion of Medicins.
div.p: IN Genere: They ar either Specifical or Univerſal. Natur it ſelf hath formed al of them Specifical, Though ſom do award, that ſom Individual Medicaments (as namly, Gold, Mercury, Autimony, Amber, Magnetis, Crocus, Uvae Juniperi, Sai and Sulphur) ar Catholick: But upon a ſecond Adviſo: They wil find, that not Natur, but Art only doth ſtructurat that which is Univerſal. Only therfor in this caſ the Univerſaliſt, but not the Specificaliſt doth add any thing to Natur, as it's Adjument: However, ther be ſo many Specifick Medicaments, as ther ar Individuals therof, whether of Vegetabls, Animals or Minerals. As for the Univerſal, the Philoſophers Adept divid them into three, viz. Cur it ſelf, C • r the Great, and Hermes his Medicin, called alſo the Elixir, Pantarva, 〈◊〉 the Ens P • imum (not of the Vulgar Chymiſt) but of the Adopted S • agyriſt. This indeed is the choyceſt of all, neither can it admit of a Parallel, whether in Natur, or by Art. The other two, I cal them Panthiatiſms, and Panchymagogams. The Panthiatiſms, ar only fiv.

list.item: 1. Adquadrant to the three Radical Principles of Natur, viz. Sal, Sulphur, Mercury.

2. Analogant, to the three Anatomical ſpirits, viz. Animal, Vital and Natural, Which is indeed an Aurun • -P • tabile, not that of the Pretender, or Quacking Chymiſt; But on exactly formed as correſponding to theſ three Anatomical ſpirits, and then is it indeed The Great Cordial.
3. Correſpondent, to the four primary Qualities.
4. Homologant, to the ſeven cardinal parts of the Body; viz. The Brain, the Heart, the Liver, the Lungs, the Spleen, the Gal, and Keins.
5. Conſonant to the 12. Prop • rties and Operations of Medicin as anſwering to 12. particular extremities in Natur. Of Defect Six, viz. Numbneſs, Stupidity, Parſimony, Reflux, Influx and Increſcency.
And of Exceſs Six, viz. Senſility, fulneſs, ſuperfluity, afflux, efflux, and excreſcency.

div.p: This Medicin is only external whether in the form of a Plaiſter or of a Balſam. Al the reſt ar Internal; this the Internal-Reſtorativ, and this the External-Reſtorativ. Of the Panchymagogums ther ar three: On is Anotick, i. e. Vomitiv. Cathotick, i. e. purgativ by ſtooling, and Diuretick, i. e. by Urin. Thus is this of min, which of them all I hav as yet only mad, though all the reſt ar known to me as wel as A B C.

Another is Diaphoretick alſo: i. e. Purgativ, by Sweating. Though I no ways fancy that of the Quacks, Mountebancks and Common Chymiſts, as alſo would refrain, ſo much as wer conveniently poſſibl, from Tranſpirativ-Medicins: Yet muſt I tell you, that an Adepted Philoſoph, who knows how to form, and how to adminiſter it ſo, as not to Byas, but to track Natur in it's operation can mak a very choic Panchymagogum: alowing it a Diaphoretick-property, with the other three alſo. But the third and laſt, as it doth no ways becom the Skilles to meddl with it, it being compoſed with a Philoſophical Mixtur of the greateſt and ſtrongeſt poyſons, In lik-manner it muſt never be adminiſtred, but in deſperat caſes as namly, Cancers, Palſies, Apoplexies, the King's Evil being inveterat, Herpes, Schirrus, Leproſy, the Gout, and falling-ſickneſs.

By this, an other Quality (but a dangerous on, in an unskilful hand, though nothing lik it, for the forſaid Maladies, beſid the Elixir or Pantarva it ſelf, being arightly adminiſtred, dextrouſly formed, and prepared, this indeed is a Cur the Great) I ſay, by this an other Quality is added to the Panchymagogical Medicin, viz. The Operation by Antiperiſtacy. Thus in few words: al our Univerſal Medicins do either operat by Sympathy, (but chiefly the Philoſophical Magnet, i. e. the Panacea) as all the fiv ſorts of the Panthiatiſms abov written, among which chiefly, the Aurum Potabile: for it is, being truly formed, the very next to the Quinteſſential-Medicin it ſelf. Or elſ they do work by Antipathy, as namly all the three ſorts of Panchymagogums.

div.head: ANIMADVERSIONS.
div.p: 1. We cal it not an Univerſal Medicin, becauſ it wil undoubtedly, unavoidably, and infallibly cur al Diſeaſes; Not Hermes his Medicin it ſelf, but only the Divin Power can do this: I mean a Power far abov al that is in Natur, or Art.

2. Only my meaning is, that ſecluding divin Determination, the Pleaſur of God, or his Judgments, death it ſelf and the fatality therof, i. e. its power overcoming the vertu of the Medicin, whether by a divin hand only (as when the Elixir is adminiſtred) or by a Preter-natural activity of its own, as it is very apt to do, notwithſtanding the adminiſtration of any of all the reſt, whether Panthiatiſms, or Panchymagogums. I ſay with theſ exceptions, ther is not any Diſeaſ whatſoever, which the Catholick Medicin is not good againſt, according to all that goodneſs, which Natur and Art either do or can afford. Yea, even in theſ Limitations, it is only per accidens, and not per ſe that al Diſeaſes ar not cured by it. For as a ſharp ax, v. g. in ons hand is of it ſelf a very fit inſtrument to hew wood, ſo indeed it wel can, if nothing intervein by accident
to hinder the hewing therewith: As when this Mans Neighbour wil needs hinder him from hewing therewith, though on his part or on the part of that inſtrument in his hand, ther be nothing wanting to hew by, Yet in the Interim, by this Interveining Cauſ of his Neighbour, he is put by from hewing. Lo, al the whil, this is but per accidens and not per ſe. Juſt ſo it is, with the Univerſal Medicin of it ſelf, it is fit, and on its part, nothing wanting to Cur al Diſeaſes; Only by accident, ſomthing or other (by which it is maſtered) doth intervien, by which its vertu is interrupted, which if it had not interviened, to ſtop its Energy; without doubt it had cured, what it did not, as being of it ſelf apt to do ſo, if not interrupted by an overpowring Obſtructer.

3. Neither do I mean, That this my Panchymagogum, now in uſ is Sufficient, to perfect the Cur of al Diſeaſes Tum in Effectibus, Tum in Affectious. The very Pantarva it ſelf could not do this, as herafter will ſomwhat appear. Only this min Univerſal Purgativ doth ſerv to diſcuſs al Diſeaſes in their effects, as being of it ſelf-fitted, to remov the cauſ of al diſeaſes whatſoever, And yet by accident, upon no terms muſt it be adminiſtred to ſom Perſons: as thoſ: who ar exceſſivly weak and puny, whether by old age, or otherways: And in ſom diſeaſes as namly Pthyſis, and Tabes. Nothing for ſuch beſid the Panacaea, lik to the Great Cordial or Aurum Potabile. But they muſt ſtay, til they can get it: for I am ſur, they cannot hav it, but from the Adepti. Beſid, though indeed it is a Cur the Great; i. e. fit to Cur the greateſt of all Diſeaſes, viz. Epilepſies, Eiſtulas, Cancers, Gouts, Dropſies, Leproſies, and the reſt of thoſ deſperar Diſeaſes abov-written: yet muſt I tel you, That without the forſaid Antiperiſtatical Addition which as yet it hath not, neither do I indeed intend it (if ever at al) but in ſuch deſperat caſes, it is not and cannot be ſo Energetical, or Effectual againſt them, though even in al theſ Maladies; it is a moſt Sovereign Remedy. Whoſoever trys it wil find it ſo.

div.head: SECT. 2. The Nullity of a Specifical Pungativ.
div.p: A Specifick Medicin is that which is appropriated to this or that particular Diſeaſ, to this or that particular Humour, or to this and that particular Complexion and Conſtitution: Now, to ſpend our tim in ſuch a way of Adminiſtration, whether by Purgativs or otherwiſ, is quit beſid the Butt for reaſons which I cannot now enlarg, but only nam, becauſ tedious and endleſs, a looking into mens Urin, enquiring into Symptoms, conſidering the Complexions, feeling of Pulſes, attending on Critical days, together with the hearing of the repetitions and needles diſcourſes of the Patient or his ſubſtitut is enough verily to mak a man gray er he be old: Let me tel you, that an Adeptus can diſpatch mor Patients in a day then this drolling way can afford to do in a year: And with what differenc in point of ſucces, let Work bear but witnes of it. 2. Dangerous. 3. Hurtful. 4. Intemperat.

div.head: SECT. 3. The Neceſſity of the Univerſal Medicin.
div.p:
Neceſſary it is; firſt: Becauſ as it is temperat in its operation (though not
in the Method, Matter or Preparation, whether of Crollius or of Quercetan, ſo ſom Diſeaſes, (as Cachexia and Pthyriaſis) wher ther is a Confluenc of al humors perhaps equaly predominant, do of neceſſity requir it. I would fain know, how a Specifical Medicin can Cur that Patient, in whom at on tim Natur is oppreſſed with Diſeaſes of al humours, as indeed I hav found it by ſad experienc in my ſelf. At on tim I was afflicted with the Scurvy and Black Jaundic; ther was Melancholy: with the Yellow-Jaundic, and ther was Choler, with an inveterat Cough together with the Cholick; ther wer Pituit and Phlegm: much about the ſam tim was I alſo infeſted with the Pils, ther was Blood: Sur this could never be cured by Specificks: for that which at on tim ſhould hav corrected on diſtemper, would needs hav exaſperated his Croſs Companion.
Secondly, Becauſ all the vertuous Qualities, which indeed ſhould be in Medicins, do al at one conſpir in it, viz. Safty, Certainty, Expedition, and Efficacy.

The firſt it hath from its Preparation and Method; the third and fourth from its Matter; but the Second from all the three, i. e. from Matter, Method and Preparation: I mean, it hath al theſ properties in it ſo far, as Natur and Art either doth or can alow to any on particular Species therof in its proper Series. Thus verily is my preſent Panchymagogum formed; for by Art I hav ſo compoſed it, as that in its proper Series its Matter, Method, and Preparation ar unalterabl, to which, whether by Natur or Art, nothing can be added, nor any thing diminiſhed therfrom, Sav that in a higher and lower Series of this Medicinal Preaicament we may find the vertu of Medicins either higher or lower; but though Specificks neither hav, nor can hav al theſ Qualities in them; yet I wil tel you, that in expedition and efficacy, hie & nuns, they do exceed ſom of our Catholicks: as namly, your Mountebank-Spirits, and ſom of your pretended Quacking-Catholiks; which in effect ar but Specificks: for inſtanc, ſom of them work by the Antimonial-Cup, the antick Sulphur of Antimony, and Mercurius Vitae as Univerſal: wheras a wiſ man knoweth, that Antimony per ſe helps nothing but the Spleen, even as Mercury curs nothing per ſe, but the Maladies of the Liver: However, though Specificks per Acciden, yea and ſomtim per Antiperiſtaſin, (which maks your Ignorants, though they know not the reaſon of it, but that now I tel them it, ventur to giv them for all Diſeaſes, as ſom of them do; but others of them, (not daring to ventur ſo far, concluding the impoſſibility of an Univerſal Meaicin) do adminiſter them for many, yea for the moſt of Diſeaſes:) I ſay, though for theſ Reaſons they do counterfeit an Univerſality of operation, with a great deal of efficacy and expedition, wonderful for the tim, to al Spectators, but chiefly pleaſing to the Patient himſelf, yet be ſur of this, That Latet A • guis in Herba, I tel you, ſuch Medicins, becauſ not of a temperat operation, do only mak the Radical Moyſtur to fluſh for a tim, and flow out; but er al be don, they either quit drink it up, or elſ do exceedingly Impeach it: And ſo in proceſs of tim the Patient is quit killed, or mad worſ than better therby, ſo that in ſuch Medicins that Proverb is verify'd, Soon rip, ſoon rotten: yet muſt
I tel you, That as no Carion can kil a Crow, (ſom bodies ar ſo antidoted againſt, or rather ſo unſenſibl of Medicins that be deſtructiv to them) ſo ther is a divin hand, by which peopl (though al do not obſerv it) ar preſerved from the violenc of many things, that they receiv into their bodies, enough to kil them, and yet they do not ſo much as hurt thoſ that tak them.

div.head: SECT. 4. The differenc between a Specifick Purgativ, and that which is Reſtorativ.
div.p: Ther is not ſo much danger to adminiſter that which is Purgativ, though Specifick to al Diſeaſes, as that which is Reſtorativ and but Specifical: for, as that very currently doth evacuat per accidens, al other humors beſid to which it is not appropriated; ſo this, but hap-hazard by an Antiperiſtasy, doth cur this or that Diſeaſ, to which it is not a proper cur.

div.head: SECT. 5. The proper and genuin uſ of Specificks.
div.p: This is twofold, 1. As they ſerv for the Matter of the Univerſal Medicin, linked together by a Methodical Union, according to the Rules of Approprtation, juſt Approportion and Contemperation. 2. By themſelves, and a part to prevent that torment and other inconvenients, to which the poor Patient is expoſed by Chyrurgions Inſtruments, or of the Operators, and other hard means: Ther is indeed great uſ of theſ fiv ſorts of them. 1. Stipticks for Rupturs. 2. Attractivs for rotten-Teeth, looſ-Teeth, achd-Teeth, doubl-Teeth, Corns, and Warts. 3. Diuretick, to diſſolv and break the Ston whether in the Bladder, or Kidneys. 4. Cathareticks for Wens, and Cut-arteries. 5. Narcoticks, in caſ ſom member or other muſt needs be cut off: they wil likwiſ be great uſ of Attractivs, for Thorns, Spiks, Pricks, Splinters and the lik: I tel you plainly, even as no man by this my Panchymagogum can perfect al diſeaſes, in their effects and affects too, without the joint concurrenc, not only of all the other Panchymagogums, and Panthiatiſms, but alſo of al theſ Specificks; In lik manner, though the very Elixir or Panacaea it ſelf wer not wanting, yet room would be left, (of neceſſity too) for thoſ Specifieks abov written.

div.head: SECT. 6. The conſiſtene of Medicins.
div.p: Below the Conſiſtenc of Hermes his Medicin, Which though this be rar, yet that is but common, nothing lik to that which is in the form of a ſpirit: I would hav mad this my preſent Medicin ſo; only that as ther is a neceſſity for it's Purgativ Quality, (thus mor frequently needful, (though of it ſelf not ſo choic) than the Great Cordial.) In lik manner I behoved to refrain from this Extraction, becauſ then I ſhould have altered (at leaſt in ſom of its Materials) its Purgativ faculty: However, as now I hav formed it, it is ſo wel, as that now thou mayſt, if thou wilt, not only adminiſter it inwardly, whether in the form of Pills, or of a Liquor by Infuſion; but alſo apply it outwardly, as a P • aiſter or Balſan: Note, the higher the Preparation is, (as indeed Spirits ar of the higheſt in the vulgar part of Alchimy) the mor dangerous is that Medicin ſo prepared, if it be Specifical.

div.head: SECT. 7. The Uſ, &c. of this preſent Panchymagogum.
div.p: The Uſ.] It is twofold. 1. Operativ, i. e. It ſervs to evacuat al humors, and ſo to diſcuſs al Diſeaſes in their Cauſes and Effects. 2. Directiv, Shal I need to tel thee? That in taking it thou muſt keep warm al day, not ſtiring out of doors, walking to and again, now and then in thy room, taking it betim in the morning, by the 7 or 8 hour at leaſt, keeping thy ſelf from ſleep, til it hath don working; (yet mayſt thou tak it a bed, and reſt a litl immediatly upon it, but be ſur to be up er it fal a working;) neither eat nor drink til it hath don working: but if it be three or four hours er it work, then drink Broth mad of tender freſh meat, to provok it: When thou wouldſt hav it to cauſ vomiting, ſo much or ſo litl as thou likeſt, drink thy broth only freſh, or tak non at al, unleſs as ſaid is, too long a working: But when thou mindeſt Stooling, whether in part or moſt, or altogether, then ſeaſon thy Broth with Salt, drinking it off: In Purging bewar of al ſweet things; tak it either alon, or in a ſtewd Pruin, the pap of an Appl, or any other way thou canſt beſt do it: But chiefly obſerv theſ Twelv Directions.

list.item: 1. Except need be, tak it not but either in Spring or Fal.
2. If thy diſtemper be but ſmal, or thou doſt but tak it for Conſervation of thy health, or prevention of Diſeaſes, never tak it abov one in thoſ two ſeaſons aforſaid.
3. To prevent Relapſes, or the Return of Diſtempers, tak it duly evry Spring and Fal.
4. If thou be not either perfectly cured, or at leaſt fair on in the way after thric taking of it, ceaſ from it, for ther is but litl hops of thee.
5. Go on ſtil with it ſo long as thou findſt it doth thee good.
6. When thou muſt tak it thric on end, let ſtil a day intervein.

7. In Chronical Diſeaſes, as the Gout, Leproſy, Hypochondrick Melancholy, &c. though it betters thee al the whil, yet tak it not abov ſix tims in a quarter of a year, though thou mightſt be mor bold with it in ſpring and fal than at other ſeaſons: The frequency of taking it then for the for-ſaid Diſeaſes, I ſhal much leav to thin own diſcretion.

8. In the Cholick tak with it alſo three drops of the Oyl of Cummin-ſeed, poured into Sack Poſſet mad of half a pint of Sack, drink it off warm an hour either after or befor thou takeſt the Panchymagogum it ſelf.
9. For the Pils and Varices, ſee thou let blood alſo by Leeches applied to the Hemorrhoick veins.
10. But in the Apoplexy let blood in the left foot.
11. In the Pleuriſy of Blood, let blood ſtil in that foot which is juſt contrary to that ſid wher the malady lieth.

12. In the Apoplexy it cannot wel be given but in a Liquor, and ſo, by Infuſion: This muſt be don alſo both by great cunning and great forc: Then wil it be needful withal, to ſhav off the hair, and to rub the head, (at leaſt to do this) very ſtrongly with hard linnen cloths wel warmed.

div.p: The Doſ.] On Pill at moſt, conſiſting of about 7 Grains. He muſt be no ordinary man that wil tak abov this: ther lies much of the Cur in a juſt Proportion of the Doſ. Do thou therfor after Tryal tak ſpecial Notic whether thou tookeſt too much or too litl, til thou ſhalt find out how much of it indeed wil fit thee; without addition or diminution: Remember, That the weak, infirm, and tender, muſt tak but the Infuſion of it in a Gil of Sack, being ſet to infuſ 24 hours, therafter wel warmd in a Pottinger on liv-coals, and then gently ſtrained thorow a clean cloth, drink it immediatly off: for a child it wil ſerv for 3 or 4 tims: and for the weaker ſort of men and women the half of it wil ſerv at a tim: But yet I ſay, do thou by thin own Experienc after onc or twic taking of it, find out how much of it, to a point, wil ſerv thy Turn. In infuſing ſee thou mix it and ſtir it wel about in the Sack, knowing, that though it be clammy, yet the Liquor wil ſtil waſh it off from that with which thou ſtirreſt it about: In the Infuſion thou mayſt ſafely giv it in al manner of Fevers, not excepting the Hectick it ſelf, provided it be not already turned into the Conſumption: Whit Win to infuſ in, for Fevers; the Spirit of Win good, to mak Infuſions by.
The Pric.] On Shilling per Pill, conſidering how that in a litl Quantity thou haſt what is ſufficient for thee at onc, though as ſtrong as moſt men.

The Places wher, and the Perſons by whom, it is to be had,] ar John Fenſield, in Toolies-Street, near London Bridg, in Flowr de Luce Yard, the ſecond Door. And John Eames Hoſier, living under Cripſ-Gat Church, (ſo called.)

div.head: SECT. 8. An Account of the Author himſelf.
div.p:
My nam I ſhal conceal; for as I lov not that my Medicin by ſom ſhould be deſpiſed becauſ of me; ſo I lik not that I ſhould be adored by any, becauſ of it. A Mechanick I am not: But to thoſ that ask who I am, and how I cam by al this Knowledg, Let theſ few things ſuffic for an Anſwer. 1. I was bred a Scholar at the Univerſity it ſelf. 2. I hav parts and abilities of Natur as other men. 3. The Manifeſtation of the Spirit is given to me as wel as to others, to profit withal: I cannot ſay that ever I had this by Books; for they hav been rather a Hindranc then Furthranc to me in point of Knowledg, though I hav read and peruſed many. 4. I hav been a Student and Practitioner in this Art about 12 years: in which tim I hav cured theſ remarkabl Diſeaſes, viz. The Cholerica Paſsio, the Anaſarca, the Dyſenteria, the Rickets, the Virgin, or Green-Sickneſs, the Tertian Agu, the Gonorrhaea, the Convulſion, the Catarrh, Phlegmens, Impoſthumations, Deafneſs, the Ston and Herpes: I hav had Experienc enough, wer it no mor, but on min own body, which from a child hath been infeſted with al theſ Diſeaſes tim after tim, viz. The Smal Pox, the Meaſels, Burning Fevers, the Agu, the Gonorrhaea, the Kings Evil, Heart-burning, St • angury, Sc • lding of urin • , Tooth-ach, Watering-eys, the Non Retention of Urin, the Scurvy, the Cramp, the Itch, Scaldneſs of head, the Windy Ruptur, the Diarrhaea, Belly-ach, Yellow jaundic, Black jaundic, Inveterat Coughs, the Unnatural heat in my head, the Pils, Swouning, Spitting of Matter, Hypochondrick Melancholy, Conſtipation, Dandriff, Obſtruction of the Bowels, Quincy, Morbus Ficalis, Hectick Fever, Tumors, and Palpitation of the Heart, in al 35 ſeveral-ſorts of
Diſeaſes, 9 of which at onc infeſted me, and 7 (non of the ſmaleſt of them neither) anoyed me at another tim altogether; yea, twic in leſs than 3 years was I ſick unto death, and each tim was I afflicted with Diſeaſes 6 months together, inſomuch that the laſt tim I could not ſtir to let my Bed be mad for abov 17 weeks together: And but latly by a miſchanc was my fac poyſoned, (ſom of it got into my eys, ſom down my throat) with about 2 Ounces of the ſtrongſt poiſon that is, excepting the Black Toad of the Philoſophers: I pray by what hav I hitherto cured al theſ Diſeaſes on my ſelf? Is not her room enough for Experienc? Yet tel I you plainly, By no Medicin that Art frams. Though, ſinc my ſtudy of Phyſick I hav not been wanting to my ſelf therin, not ſuffring any other to medl with me. I hav that which no man knows but he that hath it, by which I cur both my ſelf and others too, now and then, far abov that of Hermes himſelf▪ but enough of this: Only now I declar, both conſcientiouſly (in the ſight of God) as a good man, and knowingly, as a Wiſ man, That this Medicin of min, in its proper Series, is ſo good as that it cannot be bettred by Natur or Art: If therfor thou art not bettered but worſted after taking it, I can wel tel thee, and perſwad thee alſo, with good reaſon ſo to judg, without a Ridl, why it is ſo: No doubt either becauſ not following the forgoing Directions, or becauſ ſmiten of God: for in reaſon I can aſſur, ther is no reaſon why being taken debito Modo, & debito Tempore, it ſhould wrong any, ſeeing by Art it is ſo ſtructured as that if it do no good of it ſelf, it can do no man harm, unleſs it be in this, That it hath not ſo much vertu to communicat to thee, as hath that, which is far better; I mean the Panacaea or Elixir, i. e. the Quinteſſenc. (not the pretended ones of the vulgar Chymiſt) an Arabiax Word, bearing ſuch a ſignification: Though not the Peripatiſts, yet ſur Hermet • sts, Turbiſts, and Ca • aliſts know wel what is meant by it. Howbeit, tak my Medicin as it is, (unles thou judgeſt thy ſelf unworthy of it) and blam not it, whether becauſ of thin own miſgovernanc, or becauſ of thin own iniquities, which peradventur wil reſtrain the bleſſing of it from thee; for wherin I commend it, The Great Jehovah knoweth, I ly not; And to him therin do I appeal.

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
div.p: BEſid what formerly I did intend, I muſt needs add a few words mor, though I had already hinted them in the forgoing Diſcourſ: a Word is enough to the Wiſ, as the Proverb is: yet he that hath to do with peopl of al ſorts, muſt needs fit his words (if poſſibl) to al their Capacities, to prevent either their Malicious or Ignorant Miſtaks, that room be not left for Reproach: Be therfor adviſed with me, for thy better ſatisfaction, to conſider theſ three things:

Firſt, As it is very eaſy to form a Medicin, which worketh intemperatly, whether too litl or too much: So ever ſinc I did apply my ſelf to the ſtudy of Ph • ſick, I did chooſ rather to err by Defect, (knowing that therby ther is leſs hurt, than by the other extream) than by Exceſs: I confeſs neither of them
is good; yet ſur I am, a violent Medicin doth wrong thee mor than what is lenitiv and gend: and it's the great endeavor of the Patient's ſafty, that provoks me by al means poſſibl to avoid al Exceſs and violent Medicins, wel knowing, That al ſuch do no leſs waſt his Radical Moyſtur, (without which the body is but dead) than as doth the fir of the Lamp conſum its Oyl. Secondly, It is the common ignoranc of Patients, That the beſt Medicin is that, which worketh moſt: In their conceit, (which is their deceit) it cannot be good; unleſs it mak them very ſick, giv them many Stools, and many Vomits, never minding al the whil, That though ſuch Medicins do powerfully ſcour the Humors, yet do they then as powerfully grat on Natur it ſelf. Now al thoſ Phyſitians (though ſom do it by Ignoranc alſo) who mind their own profit mor, then the Patients good, obſerving this to be the common miſtak of al peopl, do therfor apply themſelvs herin, to gratify the deluſion of their Patient. To work therfor go they, with the ſtrongeſt Medicin, that may be, both for Matter and Preparation, on purpoſ to mak a ſpeedy Cur of their Patient; (knowing that this wil pleaſ him beſt) which indeed is but a ſpeedy riddanc of the diſeaſed, and not of the Diſeaſ, ſeeing (as ſaid is) al ſuch Medicins do, the ſelf ſam way, Conſum the Radical Moyſtur, even as the fir doth waſt the Talow of a Candl, or the Oyl of a Lamp: Her indeed is efficacy but not ſafty; Now I am for both, Neither wil I indeed (to get my ſelf a nam) humor the Patient to his hurt, by adminiſtring a Medicin to him, which is both Efficacious, and Expedicious (This to do is the Eaſieſt of a 1000. I can do it as wel as other men) if it be not both ſaf and ſur alſo. Thirdly, It is wel known to me, That this my preſent Medicin, As it is moſt ſaf, (ſur I am, if it do thee no good, it wil do thee no harm, unles it be by, taking too litl or too great a Quantity of it at a tim) ſo it is as ſtrong, powerful, effectual, and expeditious, as either Natur or Art, either wil or can alow it to be, with ſafty and ſurty alſo: or indeed any Medicin can be, or ought to be, under Hermes his Medicin it ſelf. Nothing adminiſtred for frequent or common uſ, either is or can be, (beſid the Elixir) mor efficacious, and ſaf too, than it is, God knoweth. Only the Patient may Reproach and miſtak it for theſ reaſons; Of which I muſt now Remind him. 1. Blaming it for Virtu not for Vic, i. e. Becauſ it doth not work ſo ſtrongly, (That I ſay not ſo dogedly) as other Medicins do. Alow me to tel thee, as I hat to giv thee any Phyſick, (which I am ſur evry on in their Adminiſtrations, walketh not by this Rul) but What I'l tak my ſelf; yea, and giv the Bab on the Breaſt, as wel, though not in the ſam quantities; as him that is com to ag, To the weak, (though not in a manner quit conſumed) as wel as to the ſtrong; [Thus in al points it is the liker the Great Elixir:] So I declar to thee without a figur, (unles I had a mind to do him a miſchief, and ſought not his health) I would not giv that Phyſick to a Dog, which I knew would either mak him very ſick, or ſcour him very much, whether upwards or downwards: Wel, I reckon that exces of Sickneſs, which purgeth any further, then what provoks the Scouring with delight and eaſ: And that I cal Exces in Scouring, which from 6 as the Beſt, doth exceed 8 or 12 times at the moſt. 2. Blaming me for Impoſsibility, i.e. Becauſ I do not determin to a Point, and that at the very firſt daſh an exact Doſ for every perſon; a thing impoſſibl to be don without reiterated experienc, for this cauſ I hav much left it to thin own Tryal, To find out the exact Doſ without Addition or Diminution, for thin own body, after Twic or Thric taking it. The performanc of the Cur doth much lie in the exactneſs of the Doſ, as hath been ſaid already. Which being onc effected, Be thou alſo aſſured, that, God bleſſing it to thee, it wil perform al that her is ſpoken, touching it. Wheras the Doſ being either too littl it wil work too littl, or may be non at al, or too much, it wil work too much, and it may be, whether by Antiperiſtaſy, or by a ſecret reſtraint of Providenc, but litl or non at al. However, This I determin to the beſt of my knowledg that on Bill of 7 Grains is a ſufficient Doſ for any ordinary perſon whoſoever. 3 Blaming me for what God doth, or wil not do, i. e. Becauſ it may be, he Reſtrains the virtu of it from thee, cauſing it do thee-harm, making it not work, or but litl, or too much; Yea, and though when it hath acted its Part to a point, perhaps, as ſaid is, He maks it either do thee no good at al. Or it may be prejudic, not bleſſing, but curſing it to thee, partly for thin own Iniquities, and partly for a Tryal to me, Schooling me therby not to truſt in the Creatur, but in himſelf alon. 4. Blaming me perhaps for Caſualties, whether ordinary or extraordinary; ſom miſchanc or other may happen thee, to the Retardment, Obſtruction and Prejudic of the Medicin: But mor likly thin own Negligenc, in not obſerving my Directions punctualy, or beſid thy intemperat living, whether by Penury, (it may be neceſſity) or Exorbitancy. 5. Blaming the Medicin,
becauſ it wil not humor thee, but Natur, i.e. Becauſ ſomtims it wil needs Track Natur, inclining the ſam way only to work, as the preſent diſpoſition of the Patient leads it to, viz. If to Vomiting, to Vomit only, but if to Stooling, to Stool only, &c. This indeed is a virtu, but not a vic in it: Even as is that, viz. A Working Efficaciouſly, but faſly alſo. Without which, Neither ſhal I be a Phyſician if I cannot attain it, nor ſhalt thou be my Patient if thou wilt not hav it ſo, delighting only in that, which Scout thee to purpoſ, though not good. But putting al Reproch to a defianc, (for this Medicin ſhal be magnified mauger al Malic and Ignoranc) with the forſaid limitations: I declar again, as in the ſight of God, it may wel do thee good, but not harm, performing al that is her promiſed, concerning it. 6. Know, that the longer it is a working, the better it is provided, it works at length the ſam day thou takſt it. Blam it not for this, which is indeed a Virtu and not a Vic, though the Ignoranc of peopl is apt to count it ſo. 7. Al Dogmatick, though not Empyrick Phyſitians, do mak it their work to adminiſter no Medicin, but what is ſaf; for this Cauſ, they Trad mor in the Pharmacopean, than in the Common Chymical Preparations, in Vegetabls mor then in Minerals, Theſ indeed, unleſs in a skilful hand, far mor dangerous then thoſ. Which non verily can arightly uſ, but thoſ only who ar skilled to form Panthiatiſms, Panchymagogums aright, and the Panacean Medicin. Eightly and Laſtly; to ſatisfy peopl of al humours and diſpoſitions, I hav ſo orderd the matter, as that they may hav of this Medicin, both gentl, (for the young tender, weak and indifferent) as alſo ſtrong, for the ſtrongeſt and luſtieſt; in ſo much that in reaſon, on of ſuch Pills, [though I know, that either by a ſecret reſtreint of providenc, or by an Antiperiſtaſy, Sympathy, and Antipathy, [yea and for the ſam cauſes, the very leaſt and worſt of Medicins, may be and ar effectual, when the beſt and greateſt can not and do not avail] the ſtrongeſt Phyſick, and greateſt Doſ, that is, may be obſtructed in its operation: Or ſom hav taken [if we may credit the perſons report, which I had from his own mouth] two drams of Mercurius Dulcis at onc two hundred tims in and about the ſpac of two years obſerving no other Diet al the whil, then what he uſed to do at any other tim;) I ſay in reaſon [at leaſt what is common and uſual] on of ſuch Pills is a ſufficient Doſ, for the ſtrongeſt man that is, though the ſtrength of four ordinary Perſons. But then Such muſt expect to pay a pric equivalent to a fourfold Doſ for ordinary peopl. Theſ things I thought good to Anticipat, both by Word and Work, leſt they ſhould hav been objected to me as my Crims. Now, not regarding the Reproach or Scorn of any, (for indeed, as it is below me, ſo am I abl to juſtifi al that which is her written, befor God, Men, and Angels,; yea, and al things whatſoever.) I ſit down in reſt, with this as my Guard; Cede, Repugnanti, Cedendo, Victor abibis. Knowing wel, That as they ar but Bedlami, who expect mor from Natur or Art, or from any working or walking according to them, than what they can afford: for Nihil dat, quod non habet. Et ultra poſſe, non eſt eſſe or Nemo ultra poſſe. In lik manner had we ſuch diſcerning as to obſerv, That as the greateſt of means, by God, ar diſappointed, and that the very leaſt therof, by him, ſomtims ar exalted, Blaſting the beſt, and bleſsing the worſt of ſecondary Cauſes (Working without them, with them, againſt them, and abov them, at his pleaſur) we ſhould then neither Deify the Greateſt, nor Contemn the Leaſt of created means; Though ſtil in an abſolut dependency on the Vncreated Being of the Two, chooſ the beſt and the greateſt, as the liklieſt and ſafeſt things for us to mak uſ of. However, Though now thou mayſt hav that which is ſo efficacious, as any ſafty wil alow; yet is it without the forſaid Antiperiſtatical Mixtur of the ſtrongeſt Poyſons, which the Adept never did, nor do mak uſ of, but in caſ of thoſ Diſeaſes, which they cal the four Stagers, viz. The Gout, the Dropſy, the Falling-Sickneſs and Leproſy, with other deſperat Diſeaſes abov-written, which gaind them both Credit and Succeſs in their Attempts, calling it therfor Cur the Great. Wheras their pretended Imitators, ignorant of Matter, Method and Preparation, of this Medicin, eſſay to do the lik, without Reſpect either to Perſons or Diſeaſes, to the quit killing of ſom, and, at the beſt, to the great hazard of the livs of others: which, though eſcaped a preſent Lurch, yet is that therby left behind, (to judg in reaſon, ſetting aſid how God may otherways diſpoſ of it) which wil needs ſhotten their days. Al theſ things I thought good to add, beſid this, viz. That it is the Common and groſs miſtak of peopl, hand over head to tak any thing that coms next to hand, which wil but Scour them, whether upwards or downwards, never
heeding the fitneſs, whether of the Matter, Method, or Preparation. Many things they may hav to evacuat Humors, whether by Sweating, Vomiting, by Vrin, or Stooling. But few, namly as they uſ them, do do any of theſ wel: Wheras my preſent Panthymagogum is of the very beſt Matter, [Method, no doubt) and Preparation, that can be, for any ſuch Medicin in its proper Series] Of Cur-al, though not of Cur the Great, (Thus it only wants the forſaid Antiperiſtatical Addition; as ſaid is) it is the very Non-ultra. Know alſo, That the Degrees of my Medicin ar Three, anſwering al Tempers and diſpoſitions. 1. For the Weak. 2. For the ordinary-Strong. 3. for the ſtrongeſt of al, or mor then what is Ordinary. The Outmoſt Doſ, as I now judg however Providenc or Experienc may alter it, whether by Sympathy, Antipathy, or Antiperiſtaſy, for the Ordinary a Pill of 7 Grains, and for perſons that be very Robuſt, on of a Scrupl, But al the 3. ſorts, as they find occaſion for it, may uſ it, whether with or without Infuſion. Yet do I adviſ the weaker ſort, to mak much uſ of Infuſion: yea and neither weak nor ſtrong in Fevers or in any Diſeaſ, that hath brought them very low, to uſ it without Infuſion, proportioning the Doſ according to their then preſent ſtat, i. e. The ſtrongeſt then not venturing, abov 5. or 7 Grains at the moſt. But in this, Experienc wil be thy beſt Directrix, making Tryal of it by degrees, as need is. Be it alſo known to thee, That even as never any, but Prophetick and Apoſtolick Spirits knew the perfect Vniverſal Method, In lik manner without it, The Higher the Matter and Preparation be, the worſ is the Medicin.

div.head: SVB-POSTSCRIPT.
div.p:
EVen as by obſerving the various Sentiments of peopl, I did therfor unexpectedly, and undeſiredly, ſuperad the precedent Poſtſcript; In lik manner, I do now much mor adjoyn to al that forgoeth a few memorabl Notabilia, touching the Medicin it ſelf, occaſioned by an Experimental Obſervation of its Virtuous Quality and Operation. Both this, together with the Poſtſcript, wer added de Novo, ſinc the Diſcourſ it ſelf was given into the Preſs: Sith therfor a perfect Medicin, as indeed this is, in its proper Series doth requir a perfect Narration concerning it: And I my ſelf in the Interim not willing to leav any ſton unturnd, becauſ I would needs obviat al Objections, and adminiſter al reaſonabl ſatisfaction to al perſons, to prevent al Miſunderſtandings, Miſcarriages and Abuſes, that in the uſ of this Medicin may occur: I hav put my ſelf to al this pains, though with the neceſſity of uſing the Trop,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 too too much. But this wil be eaſily excuſed, that which forgoeth being duly conſider'd. Now to the purpoſ. 1. As becauſ of its Method, it can hardly, if at al, work too violently, Though adminiſtred in an Exceſſiv-giftedneſs: So becauſ of its Matter, and Preparation, it doth no harm but good to the Patient, even when it doth not work at al ſenſibly, Ther being either but too litl a Quantity of it taken, or elſ becauſ that is wanting in the Doſ, by which its Energy is heightned: for even then it doth work Magneticaly, with a ſenſibl advantag to the patients health, though al the whil unſenſibl of its Operation. I can aſſur him, (to ſpeak both in Reaſon, and from Experienc) It wil neither harm him by too violent working: for this it cannot do, though taken at onc, I know not how much of it. Yet let non ventur too far this way, as being neither profitabl nor Expedient. With the ſam aſſuranc alſo, do I avouch, That it wil not Venom, as other Medicins do, thy body, even though to thy feeling it did not work at al, ſeeing it doth operat Magneticaly alſo; In this aſſimulating the Magnet of the Philoſophers. 2. If at the very firſt it doth ſtrongly evacuat, whether by Vomiting or by Stooling, as indeed it doth in new Radicated Maladies: for inſtanc, a Cough or Cold newly catch'd, Then know, that though then it doth evacuat much, yet not often: for Nihil violentum, durabile. Wheras, in Rooted Diſeaſes, v. g. The Gout, of 9 Months continuanc, it doth then ſo grapl with the Radicated humors, as that it doth not ſpend its Vertu al at onc, and by wholſal, but peircing into the very Roots of the Malady, it doth work Gradatim, not much at onc, but of long continuanc, er it ſtay its working. As hath been formerly hinted, it doth track Natur, but not byas it: So now I ſay, It doth Track the very Diſeaſ it ſelf, fitting its Modus Operandi, to the very Modus Morbi. 3. Thou muſt not always expect from it, That the greater is its Doſ or Giftedneſs, the mor therfor it wil work on thee: for thou wilt ſomtims find it lik to Sugar, and other things that I might inſtanc, But that this is ſo wel known, which, as it wil not be diſſolved by the
ſtronger, but by the weaker Liquor poured upon it: So not a great, but a ſmal Quantity of the ſam doth diſſolv it beſt: Do not therfor mind its Quantity, but Quality, not its Bulk, but its Vertu: for as the Proverb is, Magnitudo non eſt Virtus. Experienc, as formerly hinted, therfor in this caſ, wil be thy beſt Directrix, how to Coaptat its Giftedneſs and Fabrick. Howb cit, Knowing very wel that the Eternal Jehovah doth ſway al things at his pleaſur, ſomtims cauſng Fools do what the wiſ cannot, the Vnskilful do what the Skilful cannot, the Weak what the Strong can not, the Artles what Artiſts cannot, the unlearned what the Learned cannot, and the Wicked do, what the Godly cannot, making ſmal means, bad means, things meanly prepar'd badly prepar'd, not prepar'd at al, meanly, badly, not at al arightly Compoſed, Ordred and Adminiſtred, Scarcly, Indifferently yea not at al, but quit deſtructiv to Natur: Making, I ſay, ſuch things Effectual and Profitabl, Wheras their virtuous Oppoſits ar rendred Ineffectual and uſles by him, hic & nunc, (yea frequently too, though the ſons of Men obſerv it not) at his pleaſur: Vpon this ſerious Conſideration, God is my witnes I ly not, I cannot, I muſt not, I dar not, and I wil not, Boaſt my ſelf in any thing, but Jehovah only, not taking upon me to outveigh the wickedſt or meaneſt Practitioner that either is or can be. Only, al that undoubtedly and with Confidenc I can promiſ thee, concerning this my Medicin, in its own Nam, be theſ two things: On is, That in its proper Series, without Addition or Diminution, it is a perfect Medicin in that ſenſ of perfection, as is abov-written in the Diſcourſ it ſelf. So that with this Limitation it wants for nothing, as it is in its own Series, which either Natur or Art can better it by. Another is, That in its proper Series it is, of al Medicins now in uſ, the liklyeſt and moſt probabl Expedient for Cur and Health: Not afraid to ſay, that what ever Medicin, her or ther, now and then doth exceed it in this or in that, It is not becauſ of excelling it by Art, whether in Matter, Method, or Preparation: for this cannot be, as it is in its proper Series. Only it is by a hidden Property, as ſom phraſ it; Which I ſay, is either by Providenc or by Sympathy, Antipathy, or by Antiperiſtaſy. However, Let God do the Beſt, but us chuſ the Liklieſt, as the Proverb goeth. To add a Diaphoretick Quality to it, which I could ſoon do, I do not much fancy that; but far leſs that which is by Sneezing and Salivation. And ſhould I ſuperadd therto the forſaid Antiperiſtatical Property, with a Tric this might be don alſo, and therby Tranſlat it in to a higher Series: for then properly itwould be that which is called Cur the Great, being only a loted for the greateſt of al Diſeaſes. Yet, in this Structur, it muſt be adminiſtred to no diſtemper whatever, but only theſ, viz. The Gout, the Cancer, the Fiſtula, Noli me tangere, Herpes, Schirrous, Dropſy, Epilepſy, Struma, the Leproſy, Palſy, Morbus Gallicus, Lethargy, Varices, Phrenſy, Mania, Hypochondry, Apoplexy, Carbuncl and Plagu Sor. As for Hermes Medicin, though he not the firſt Author of it, albeit of the higheſt Series, Yet I do not herby giv accompt, whether I know it, yea or not. Only this on thing do I profeſs, That no man without the knowledg of it, either is or can be Medicus Adeptus. Yea, Neither muſt I, as yet, either Reveal, or do al that I know: for, Tempore, Fatet Occulta Verisas. Al this my carful and ſerious advic to thee, is not for min but t • in own profit, God knoweth, for I intend not to mak a Trad of Phyſick; But ſo ſoon as I can with conveniency, freely to giv▪ as I hav freely received: I ſay, my Advic is, never ceaſ from uſing it duly, both Spring and Fal, to prevent Relapſes, the Return of Diſeaſes, and to maintain thin Health, as alſo to prevent Diſtempers. Neither think it enough, that thou art either in Part or in Whol betterd by it: But go on with it ſtil, not only til the Cur be perfected, but alſo for Accelerating the Cur, and taking away, as by the Roots, the Reliqus of the Diſeaſ, Spar not to tak of it, even when the Diſeaſ ſeems to thee to be perfectly Cured. Yea, though at on tim it anſwers not thin expectation, yet ſpar not to ventur on it again at another tim; But ſtil with that Cautiouſneſs, as is abundantly provided for, in the Directions abov-written, avoiding fleep in tim of taking it, ſo much as is poſſibl.
